article.title: Discovery of a time lag between the soft X-ray and Radio emission of the tidal disruption flare ASASSN-14li: Evidence for linear Disk--Jet coupling

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed black curve in the left and middle panels represent?
choices: The best-fit linear model to the light curves
The observed variability of the light curves
The best-fit power-law decay model to the light curves
The 3Ïƒ variability contours of the light curves

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does the right panel provide?
choices: The long-term trend of the X-ray and radio light curves
The correlation between the X-ray and radio light curves after removing their long-term trends
The time lag between the X-ray and radio light curves without any de-trending
The evolution of the radio spectral energy distribution

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the peak positions in the three CCF plots (left panels)?
choices: The X-ray emission leads the radio emission by approximately 13 days.
The radio emission leads the X-ray emission by approximately 13 days.
The X-ray and radio emission are simultaneous.
There is no significant correlation between the X-ray and radio emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the middle and right panels represent?
choices: The distribution of the peak and centroid values of the CCF, respectively, showing the uncertainty in the lag measurement.
The X-ray and radio light curves after subtracting their best-fit power-law decay models.
The auto-correlation functions of the X-ray and radio light curves, respectively.
The evolution of the spectral index of the radio emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the solid black line represent?
choices: The best-fit linear relation between the X-ray and radio luminosities
The expected relation between the X-ray and radio luminosities for a spherical expanding cloud
The best-fit power-law relation between the X-ray and radio luminosities
The expected relation between the X-ray and radio luminosities for a steady jet
Transient radio flux from the tidal disruption event
Non-transient radio flux from the pre-existing AGN
Total radio flux at any given time
Peak radio flux during the flare

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this formula indicate about the nature of the radio emission region?
choices: It is consistent with a uniformly expanding single spherical cloud model.
It suggests that the bulk of the radio emission likely originates from a conical geometry that is adiabatically expanding.
It implies that the magnetic field strength within the emission region is constant.
It indicates that the synchrotron cooling time is much shorter than the dynamical time of the emission region.
